Now we're going back to Cleveland where the Republican National Convention starts tomorrow.
When we were there last week, we caught up with one Cleveland resident excited about this week's convention, and it's not even his own party.
Democratic Senator Sherrod Brown is a longtime member of Congress from Ohio.
He was first elected in 1993 and then moved over to the Senate nine years ago.
Senator Brown was still in Washington when I called, but I had a chance to ask him whether Cleveland is ready to host the Republican National Convention.
The city's absolutely ready.
The city - we had a pretty good spring with LeBron James and the Cavaliers winning the NBA championship.
Things are very good in Cleveland now, still some issues in the neighborhoods, but we're coming back in so many good ways.
This is a different kind of event.
I mean, the fact is everybody here loves LeBron James and the Cavs, everybody does not love the presumptive nominee for the Republican Party.
And this is a pretty Democratic area.

On top of that, a number of people have promised to come and protest at this convention because they say that they feel that it is their obligation to demonstrate their opposition to the policies of the party and to this particular nominee.
Does that give you any concerns?
Oh, I'm always concerned about huge crowds and what that can mean in a city, but I'm totally confident that the people in Cleveland will be peaceful.

There are great efforts on the part of people of faith to greet delegates and to march and to do peaceful demonstrations and to exhort any outsiders that come in, that might be less inclined to do that, to in fact be peaceful.
I am hopeful that Donald Trump doesn't try to stir people up in any ways with rhetoric, as he's done in rallies elsewhere, but I'm confident in the police department in Cleveland.
I'm confident there will be lots of protests.
I'm fine with that.
It's what we do in this country.
It's healthy for democracy.
And I am confident the people of Cleveland will make sure that they will be peaceful.
Recognizing that you are not a Republican, as we said, this is not your party.
Since this is the week we're going into the Republican Convention, where the party puts on its case for the American people, is there a particular tone you would like to hear them strike?
What would you want to hear out of this convention this week?
I watched most of the debates on both sides over the last several months, as many in the country did.

I think that's good, but it - what's not good is that the hate speech may continue after the election.
So it's in my interest as a citizen of this country and as an Ohioan and as a proud Clevelander that they do tone it down and they're respectful of one another and respectful of political opponents.

Well, today is the fifth day of the hajj rituals and it requires pilgrims to stone three walls and there are two tiers where people can--pilgrims can stone these pillars, either at the top on the bridge where this tragedy occurred or at the bottom underneath.
Now the problem happened.

Basically it was absolutely a phenomenal amount of crowds that were congregated around that area and the problem is people will travel from Medina to Mecca this evening as they have been doing throughout the day.
So they take their baggage with them that they brought to Medina to stay here for the past three or four days.
They've been talking that luggage to the ritual site and that's been causing a lot of problems for people to get past.
So you're saying that the colossal crush of people was compounded by the fact that so many were carrying luggage as well as they were on these bridges?
Yes, absolutely.

Now the Saudi authorities say that their stewards and their security men did tell people to leave their luggage behind, but many people very reluctant to leave their luggage and very irresponsible in that respect because you've got lines, you've got people in wheelchairs kind of passed along the side, which makes a very large space very, very crowded very quickly.
And sadly this is, by no means, the first time that there has been a stampede and a significant loss of life on the hajj.
Are the Saudis doing enough to provide security for more than two million pilgrims who converge on this place?
Well, I can certainly say that they've tried, but I definitely believe that they could do more.
From two years ago, we should say, there was a number of lives lost then, I think almost 250 people lost in a similar stampede.
So what the Saudi authorities did then was rather than have a pillar for people to throw the stones at, they converted that pillar into a wall.
So we now have three walls, a much larger space for people to throw their stones.

So I think it's a combination certainly of Saudi authorities trying to do more to control the flow of people that go into the Gand Mosque but also etiquette of pilgrims not counting outside, not taking their luggage with them, certainly not taking elderly or sick or children to those similar sites.
Just one last point.
Is it unthinkable to suggest that perhaps the number of pilgrims should be less than 2.5 million, that perhaps the holy sites just can't stand this volume of people?
Well, the Saudi authorities do issue a certain number of visas, hajj visas, for people to perform the hajj.
This year, as you say, almost two and a half to three million people performed it.
One thing they have not been able to control, however, is the number of people within the kingdom that come perform the hajj.
This year they're estimating almost 400,000 people are here illegally, that means basically without the hajj permit, without the authorities saying, `Yes, you can perform this hajj.'
Rabiya Parekh, thank you very much for talking with us today.
Thank you.

That's Rabiya Parekh who's a reporter for the BBC World Service, who has been at the hajj and is talking to us from Medina, Saudi Arabia, where earlier today more than 300 people, Muslim pilgrims, died in a stampede.
